DataElement.preferredName: Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Amino Acid Coding Status CodingStatus
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, present at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population._Organic compounds containing amino (-NH2) and carboxyl (-COOH) groups.  In biochemistry, used to refer to the twenty-plus L-alpha-amino acids found in proteins.:The activity of implementing rules that are used to map the elements of one set onto the elements of another set, usually on a one-to-one basis.:A condition or state at a particular time._Coding status

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, present at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population.

Concepts.definition: A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, present at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population.

In biochemistry, used to refer to the twenty-plus L-alpha-amino acids found in proteins.:The activity of implementing rules that are used to map the elements of one set onto the elements of another set, usually on a one-to-one basis.:A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: Any organic compounds containing amino (-NH2) and carboxyl (-COOH) groups.  In biochemistry, used to refer to the twenty-plus L-alpha-amino acids found in proteins.
The activity of implementing rules that are used to map the elements of one set onto the elements of another set, usually on a one-to-one basis.
A condition or state at a particular time.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Complex Single Nucleotide Polymorphism in Coding Sequence

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Complex Single Nucleotide Polymorphism in Coding Sequence
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in Coding Sequences consist of a variation at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population of a single nucleotide, due to base substitution, at an equivalent location within a protein-coding region of a gene that may or may not cause an amino acid change in the protein product and a detectable phenotypic effect.:Hard, involved or complicated, elaborate, having many parts.

Concepts.definition: Hard, involved or complicated, elaborate, having many parts.

Concepts.longName: Single Nucleotide Polymorphism in Coding Sequence
Concepts.definition: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in Coding Sequences consist of a variation at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population of a single nucleotide, due to base substitution, at an equivalent location within a protein-coding region of a gene that may or may not cause an amino acid change in the protein product and a detectable phenotypic effect.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A Non-synonymous Coding SNP consists of a variation at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population of a single nucleotide, due to base substitution, at an equivalent location within a protein-coding region of a gene that causes an alteration of the translation of the affected codon into a different amino acid in the protein product. A missense non-synonymous SNP results in an amino acid change in the protein product due to a codon change, while a nonsense non-synonymous SNP results in a termination codon.

Concepts.definition: A Non-synonymous Coding SNP consists of a variation at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population of a single nucleotide, due to base substitution, at an equivalent location within a protein-coding region of a gene that causes an alteration of the translation of the affected codon into a different amino acid in the protein product. A missense non-synonymous SNP results in an amino acid change in the protein product due to a codon change, while a nonsense non-synonymous SNP results in a termination codon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Synonymous Coding SNP consists of a variation at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population of a single nucleotide, due to base substitution, at an equivalent location within a protein-coding region of a gene that causes no amino acid change in the protein product and no detectable phenotypic effect; a silent mutation.

Concepts.definition: Synonymous Coding SNP consists of a variation at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population of a single nucleotide, due to base substitution, at an equivalent location within a protein-coding region of a gene that causes no amino acid change in the protein product and no detectable phenotypic effect; a silent mutation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.
